comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
There can't be many railway stations with a distinctive bark roof! From Wikipedia ( www.en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toongabbie,_New_South_Wales ) -
"In 1860, the railway was extended to Blacktown but it took 20 years before any arrangements were made for trains to stop at Toongabbie." and "The original unstaffed station opened on the 26th April, 1880 and was upgraded over the years with additional platforms and loading facilities. In the late 1880s the first rail official was appointed to manage the station, a Miss Amy Arnold."
I wonder if that lady is Amy Arnold in the late 1880s?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Toongabbie, NSW (c.1920) [SLNSW: bcp_06804]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet]  "30 years" ago takes that station building back to c.1890, so the bark-roofed one must be 1880s.

That washing would be covered by smoke each time a train passed.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] It might be Amy Arnold...if not, it's still great to read about a female having such an important title as station manager in the 1880s.

I've changed the date to c.1880s.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] That washing is also probably off-white :D
